name: Drug-Coated Balloon Angioplasty
description: Endovascular technique using angioplasty balloons coated with antiproliferative drugs (typically paclitaxel) to reduce restenosis. Delivers drug directly to vessel wall during inflation without leaving permanent implant. Particularly valuable in femoropopliteal disease.

mechanism.drug: Paclitaxel (most common) - antiproliferative, inhibits smooth muscle cell proliferation
mechanism.coating: Drug bound to balloon surface with excipient for transfer
mechanism.delivery: Single inflation transfers drug to vessel wall
mechanism.duration: Drug persists in vessel wall for weeks to months

femoropopliteal_disease.rationale: High restenosis rates with plain balloon or bare metal stent
femoropopliteal_disease.data: IN.PACT, LEVANT trials show superior patency

preparation.predilation: Recommended with plain balloon to create smooth surface

inflation.rationale: Allows adequate drug transfer to vessel wall

technique.handling: Minimize blood contact before inflation (wash off drug)

katsanos_meta_analysis.finding: Increased mortality signal with paclitaxel devices at 2-5 years (2018)
katsanos_meta_analysis.response: Led to FDA investigation, temporary pause

subsequent_data.conclusion: Ongoing use with appropriate patient selection

outcomes.leave_nothing_behind: No permanent implant, preserves future options

clinical_pearls: Pre-dilation is KEY - need smooth surface for drug transfer
Inflate for at LEAST 60 seconds (2-3 min ideal) for drug delivery
DCB + atherectomy combination addresses calcified lesions
Leave nothing behind philosophy - no permanent implant
learning_objectives: Explain the mechanism of drug-coated balloon therapy
Describe optimal technique for drug-coated balloon use
Discuss the paclitaxel mortality signal controversy and current evidence
